intro: Strychnos toxifera var. obliqua, commonly known as the oblique poisonwood, is a species of flowering plant native to parts of Southeast Asia. It belongs to the family Loganiaceae and is characterized by its small, clustered flowers and elliptical, often glossy leaves. The plant contains toxic alkaloids, including strychnine and brucine, which can be harmful to humans and animals. It thrives in tropical and subtropical regions, often found in moist, shaded environments. Due to its toxicity, it is typically avoided in horticulture and is more commonly encountered in its natural habitat.
